title: Thousands protest against Brexit as MPs debate Boris Johnson’s deal
text:
Anti-Brexit protestors march in London ahead of a crunch vote on the new deal (Picture: AP)

Thousands of protesters are marching in London to demand a final say on the Brexit deal.

Huge numbers are marching through the capital as part of the People’s Vote demonstration, while others are marching to stop Brexit all together.

Crowds are gathered in Hyde Park, Oxford Circus and outside Parliament, where MPs are sitting on a Saturday for the first time since the Falklands War in 1982.

Protestors adorned in EU berets and t-shirts can be seen brandishing anti-Brexit cards and placards and blimps of Boris Johnson.

People are demanding a final say on the Brexit deal (Picture: PA)

A blimp of Boris Johnson and his adviser Dominic Cummings can be seen among the crowd (Picture: Rex Features)

Thousands have descended on the capital in one of the biggest protests in history (Picture: AP)

Speaker of the House John Bercow features heavily on signs at the march (Picture: @TheNewEuropean)

Pro remain protesters are marching from Hyde Park to Parliament to demand a People’s Vote (Picture: Rex Features)

Mayor of London Sadiq Khan is among the protesters.

Writing in the Independent, he said Boris Johnson is offering the British people ‘a terrible false choice on Brexit’ – between a bad deal and a no-deal.

He described today’s march as ‘one of the biggest, most important and most historic protests this country has ever seen’ as he called on the PM to give the public the final say on Brexit.

He said: ‘We will be marching together, not because we despair of our democracy, but because we want to defend it.’

Mayor of London Sadiq Khan says the march is the last chance to defend democracy (Picture: Rex Features)

A Stop Brexit and a People’s Vote March is taking place at the same time (Picture: Rex Features)

Protesters push a float depicting Dominic Cummings outside the Houses of Parliament in London after Boris Johnson delivered a statement on his new Brexit deal (Picture: PA)

Some protesters are putting on a performance during the March as thousands flock to central London (Picture: AP)

Pro-remain groups donned in EU gear, calling on the government to give Britons a vote on the final Brexit deal (Picture: REUTERS)

MPs are set to vote on Boris Johnson’s new Brexit deal later today.

However that may be derailed if the Letwin amendment – which seeks to delay Brexit until all legislation to implement withdrawal is passed.

People from across the country have flocked to London to protest against the new deal.

Transport companies have reported a record number of bookings’ on coach journeys to London.

The demonstration will be heading from Park Lane to Parliament Square this afternoon.

The march will go via Piccadilly, St James’s Street, Pall Mall, Cockspur Street, Trafalgar Square and Whitehall.

MPs are set to vote on Boris Johnson’s deal later today (Picture: EPA)

The protest has brought much of central London to a standstill (Picture: Sky News METROGRAB)

Some pro-Brexit protesters have turned up outside the Houses of Parliament (Picture: PA)

Pro-Brexit demonstrators clash with anti-Brexit demonstrators in Parliament Square (Picture: AFP)

Roads have been closed as hundreds march for a ‘meaningful vote’ (Picture: Reuters)

It has brought much of central London to a standstill, with road closures in place on the route and its approaches.

People travelling to central London have been advised to take extra time for their journeys and consider alternative routes.

Trains will not stopping at Green Park station to prevent overcrowding while crowd control measures are in place.

Small numbers of pro-brexit supporters can be seen among the crowds.
